body:
Hello @KosukeHao, thank you for your interest in our work! Please visit our [Custom Training Tutorial](https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov3/wiki/Train-Custom-Data) to get started, and see our [Google Colab Notebook](https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov3/blob/master/tutorial.ipynb), [Docker Image](https://hub.docker.com/r/ultralytics/yolov3), and [GCP Quickstart Guide](https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov3/wiki/GCP-Quickstart) for example environments. 
  
If this is a bug report, please provide screenshots and **minimum viable code to reproduce your issue**, otherwise we can not help you.

P and R are not important, as these are user-selectable simply by varying --conf. mAP encompasses these two metrics at all --conf, so just worry about mAP. 

See https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov3/issues/898

Hello @glenn-jocher,  firstly, thanks for your great work! 
I also have a similar problem with this issue. When I train on my own dataset with single class, using 4 GPUs，with batch_size is 16, the R and P and mAP are all low, mAP is only 0.25 no matter how many epoch I train, and if I stop training and restart training with --resume, the P and R and mAP will all near 0.99, I think this result is not correct, because when I test the model on a picture, it can not detect anything. Then I go back to check the test_batch0_pred.jpg, I found that only 1/4 of the pictures were detected normally, and the remaining 3/4 of the pictures were not detected at all，so I guess this result has something to do with multi GPU training. Then I tried to train on a single GPU, at this time, the network converges normally after a few epoch as expected. But after training more than 10 epochs, loss becomes non and the training stops.
I hope you can help me to solve these two questions. Thank you again for your outstanding work！

@suzhr3 nan loss is caused by divergence. There are several issues on the subject here, please do a search.

Recommend not using --resume, but rather training fully using all default parameters with latest repo.

> P and R are not important, as these are user-selectable simply by varying --conf. mAP encompasses these two metrics at all --conf, so just worry about mAP.
> 
> See #898

mAP is also low when train from scratch, but high when train with --resume, even after first epoch.

@KosukeHao --resume is only for emergency use, i.e. when your server restarts over the weekend or something. It should never be used if it can be avoided. Always train fully if possible, i.e. 0-300 epochs in one go.

> > P and R are not important, as these are user-selectable simply by varying --conf. mAP encompasses these two metrics at all --conf, so just worry about mAP.
> > See #898
> 
> mAP is also low when train from scratch, but high when train with --resume, even after first epoch.

have you found the solution? i check the hyparams setting are consistant, but the map is so low in training time.
Do not use resume. Train fully from start to finish.

> Do not use resume. Train fully from start to finish.

Hi Glenn, thanks for your reply. I tried docker run and found all these problems disappeared. Not only this recall and map issue, but also the "expected xxx on cuda, but found on 'cpu'" problem in training(no --multi-scale) and testing (this line "_ = model(torch.zeros((1, 3, imgsz, imgsz), device=device)) if device.type != 'cpu' else None  # run once"  on test.py).
I've decided to run on docker now. I think you are also running on docker.


Update: Sorry for my carelessness, docker doesn't solve this problem.

@nightsnack yes, we train on GCP, docker and colab. If you're starting a new project FYI I would recommend our new repo:
https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov5

> @nightsnack yes, we train on GCP, docker and colab. If you're starting a new project FYI I would recommend our new repo:
> https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov5

Sorry, I  didn't look into details yesterday. Even if on docker, this problem still appears.
Here is what I run.
( I directly pull your docker image and run. I also tried build one. Same results.)

`python train.py --data coco2014.data --weights '' --batch-size 64 --device 0,1 --cfg yolov3-spp.cfg --img 320`

**I do pycocotools map test every epoch.** and do not modify any other code.
**results of training:**
 Epoch   gpu_mem      GIoU       obj       cls     total   targets  img_size
               Class    Images   Targets         P         R   mAP@0.5        F1: 100%|██████████| 79/79 [00:39<00:00,  2.92it/s]                 all     5e+03  3.51e+04     0.386    0.0633    0.0697    0.0981
**COCOTOOLS API RESULTS:**
 Average Precision  (AP) @[ IoU=0.50:0.95 | area=   all | maxDets=100 ] = 0.03802
 Average Precision  (AP) @[ IoU=0.50      | area=   all | maxDets=100 ] = 0.07400
 Average Precision  (AP) @[ IoU=0.75      | area=   all | maxDets=100 ] = 0.03538
 Average Precision  (AP) @[ IoU=0.50:0.95 | area= small | maxDets=100 ] = 0.01292
 Average Precision  (AP) @[ IoU=0.50:0.95 | area=medium | maxDets=100 ] = 0.03695
 Average Precision  (AP) @[ IoU=0.50:0.95 | area= large | maxDets=100 ] = 0.05070
 Average Recall     (AR) @[ IoU=0.50:0.95 | area=   all | maxDets=  1 ] = 0.04970
 Average Recall     (AR) @[ IoU=0.50:0.95 | area=   all | maxDets= 10 ] = 0.08618
 Average Recall     (AR) @[ IoU=0.50:0.95 | area=   all | maxDets=100 ] = 0.09785
 Average Recall     (AR) @[ IoU=0.50:0.95 | area= small | maxDets=100 ] = 0.02721
 Average Recall     (AR) @[ IoU=0.50:0.95 | area=medium | maxDets=100 ] = 0.10094
 Average Recall     (AR) @[ IoU=0.50:0.95 | area= large | maxDets=100 ] = 0.12489

Then I use python test.py to test the weights/best.pt which map **should be around 0.0697**.
Look what I get:
               Class    Images   Targets         P         R   mAP@0.5        F1: 100%|█████████████████| 313/313 [01:23<00:00,  5.52it/s]
                 all     5e+03  3.51e+04     0.341     0.154     0.151     0.177
              person     5e+03  1.05e+04     0.442     0.555     0.504     0.492
             bicycle     5e+03       313     0.547    0.0511     0.101    0.0935

 Average Precision  (AP) @[ IoU=0.50:0.95 | area=   all | maxDets=100 ] = 0.078
 Average Precision  (AP) @[ IoU=0.50      | area=   all | maxDets=100 ] = 0.151
 Average Precision  (AP) @[ IoU=0.75      | area=   all | maxDets=100 ] = 0.073
 Average Precision  (AP) @[ IoU=0.50:0.95 | area= small | maxDets=100 ] = 0.029
 Average Precision  (AP) @[ IoU=0.50:0.95 | area=medium | maxDets=100 ] = 0.074
 Average Precision  (AP) @[ IoU=0.50:0.95 | area= large | maxDets=100 ] = 0.107
 Average Recall     (AR) @[ IoU=0.50:0.95 | area=   all | maxDets=  1 ] = 0.138
 Average Recall     (AR) @[ IoU=0.50:0.95 | area=   all | maxDets= 10 ] = 0.271
 Average Recall     (AR) @[ IoU=0.50:0.95 | area=   all | maxDets=100 ] = 0.323
 Average Recall     (AR) @[ IoU=0.50:0.95 | area= small | maxDets=100 ] = 0.114
 Average Recall     (AR) @[ IoU=0.50:0.95 | area=medium | maxDets=100 ] = 0.371
 Average Recall     (AR) @[ IoU=0.50:0.95 | area= large | maxDets=100 ] = 0.458

I will try your new yolov5. Cause due to this issue, I can't believe which one is the real map. I can't do anything further.
And could you please give some hints on the backbone ofyolov5-s yolov5-m yolov5-l...?
cspdarknet53spp? cspresnext50spp?

> @nightsnack do not use --resume.

I didn't resume

I just run this:
`python train.py --data coco2014.data --weights '' --batch-size 64 --device 0,1 --cfg yolov3-spp.cfg --img 320`
